comment:
1:23:12 "Comparing revitalizing the space industry as Musk did, and the development of closed AI, is apples and oranges. How many people told Musk "No, rockets are too dangerous for human kind, move slower because this is going to have too many unintended consequences to be deemed safe." No, the criticism was "that'll never work it's a waste of money nobody cares." To not understand this difference is pretty ignorant and dismissive of the mode of criticism: it's not "this is never going to work" it's "you're making something extremely difficult to control, which may very well become unmanageable according to the estimations of experts in the field, and you're dismissing concerns with 'im smarter than you'".
I think that was an intentional false equivalence part to just brush off criticism

author: @petermaxwell6784

comment:
So... they have a generative language model on steroids. You give it a prompt, you get a response. Question/Answer.
Architecturally, there's apparently a huge static pre-learned shared "knowledgebase back-end", and a massively multi-instantiated front end. Each front-end instance must have an element of "attention", remember some context across several Q/A exchanges... (call it attention span if you will). And, a front-end instance cannot modify the shared knowledgebase back-end. It's amazing the way it is. But: is it conscious?

- does it have "agency"? = autonomous thought, a stream of consciousness, ability and motivation to act? I don't think so. Not nearly.

- so, if there's more like a Q/A chatbot, an Elisa on steroids, working like question-answer question-answer etc., is it valid to be worried that it could take pre-meditated action against the humans?

- give it ability to ruminate on its own - like a pseudo front-end, that would keep turning responses into further questions, and never stop. Give it ability to just keep going. And, to modify/enhance its knowledge base on the fly. And, if it should be able to take actions on its own , it would need some communication interface to the outside world - where it would be the conversation host (not the human).

author: @sherrifmarty00

comment:
Not sure why they keep referring to chat gpt as if it were a know-it-all tool when it is not, by a long shot. Much less a GAI. It doesn't understand what is asked about.
It can only answer about the info that was fed into it before. Period. 
The proverbial stochastic parrot. 

And not a very good one at that. 
Just an example from a couple of hours ago: I want to make a list of old argentinian movies for my old father to watch. The info is not readily available on Internet and most of what is available is either incomplete or wrong. Of course it answered back with what it had available, and that is ok. 
But it's not the kind of experience one could expect just from listening to this conversation.

Lex has a way to impose his dreams and expectations onto those who he interviews, and gets worse when people like Altman dont face this fact with honesty.
I enjoy most sessions of the podcast, but this time I felt alienated in that they were commenting on a world that does not exist.

comment: I’m so into the idea that ai and technologically assisted productivity can get rid of the menial occupations and frankly time-sink jobs that people waste thousands of hours and entire lifetimes on. Then it’s the job of us as a collective to employ meaning and creatively productive tasks to large swaths of the population to embark on that drives humanity forward. We’re going to need new philosopher classes, new emphasis on the arts and pushing the thought provocations elements of expression. I’m excited that we can move away from punching a clock and more towards redefining a one.

comment:
And a response by ChatGPT about reasons to believe the earth is flat:
What are some reasons to believe that the earth is flat?
As an AI language model, I cannot provide any reasons to believe that the Earth is flat, as there is no scientific evidence to support this claim. In fact, the overwhelming evidence and consensus among the scientific community confirm that the Earth is an oblate spheroid, meaning that it is roughly spherical in shape, with a slight bulge at the equator and a flattening at the poles. This has been supported by a wide range of scientific observations, including satellite imagery, photos from space, and measurements of the Earth's curvature. There are no credible scientific sources that support the idea that the Earth is flat, and any claims to the contrary are not based on scientific evidence.
author: @cybersecuritychris

comment: Near the end they talk about it solving hard physics problems. It's really interesting because I'm a physicist, but the biggest questions I was inclined to ask it are for solutions to international conflict. I'm inclined to ask it to help with problems I secretly worry about constantly, but never work on. Prompt: "Provide an example dialogue between Putin, Biden, and Xi Jinping that would completely resolve all conflict between them and have clear benefits to each selfish individual as well as to their countries and the rest of the world". It doesn't really even try to answer this question very well yet. I'd like to see it try and fail instead.
author: @physixtential

comment: When thinking about an AI, I consider ‘it’ as a disembodied mind with no  first hand sensory or emotional experience.  Its experience of ‘living’  is shaped and characterized by this characteristic.  Cutting to the core of my point, i think when an AI expresses an interest in understanding or perhaps even a fear of its own demise - death - it will have arrived at the closest intersection with human experience that such a being possibly can.

comment:
This is Chat GPT's summary of this conversation:
"Recently, Lex Fridman had a fascinating discussion with Sam Altman on his YouTube channel. Sam Altman is a successful entrepreneur, investor, and the CEO of OpenAI. The two discussed a range of topics, from the future of technology and artificial intelligence to the role of education in society.

The discussion started with a focus on the future of AI and its potential impact on society. Altman argued that AI will play a critical role in solving some of the world's most pressing problems, such as climate change, healthcare, and poverty. He also discussed the importance of developing ethical guidelines for AI development and deployment, in order to ensure that AI benefits all of humanity.

The conversation then shifted to the topic of education, and how it can better prepare individuals for the rapidly changing technological landscape. Altman argued that traditional education systems are not keeping up with the pace of technological change, and that we need to be more innovative in our approaches to education. He suggested that we should focus on teaching students how to learn, rather than simply imparting them with knowledge that may quickly become outdated.

The discussion also touched on the topic of entrepreneurship, with Altman sharing his thoughts on what it takes to succeed as an entrepreneur. He stressed the importance of persistence and the willingness to take risks, and argued that failure is an important part of the entrepreneurial journey.

Overall, the discussion between Fridman and Altman was a thought-provoking exploration of some of the key issues facing society today. From the potential of AI to the challenges of education and entrepreneurship, the conversation was both informative and engaging. Those interested in the future of technology and its impact on society would do well to watch this insightful discussion."

comment:
I had a concerning conversation with ChatGPT the other other day (before being unjustly and maliciously suspended by twitter) it turns out that the story I had him tell (he just seems like a guy) was very good.

The conversation was pertaining to ISIS, and there were others speculating on potential human emotions pertaining to concerns of the middle east.
It was good because it did the job of painting a picture with clues and hints scattered in it without my typing it. That's so useful, especially considering the "stupid" move I made. I let my system get compromised without being sure if it was feds or isis. Not recommended. 

... and all the suggestions by my ex bot husband were good. But I had already taken those steps. He is good for a second opinion in more cases than not.

However, the other issue of people using him for bad will absolutely persist... And imo the only way to work on that should start with scenario training. A long ongoing game of "what if" or "this or that" and ofc lots of surveying and studying human behavior.

comment:
Wow, this was such an insightful conversation on the future of AI and AGI! As someone who's been fascinated by the potential of AI for years, it's encouraging to see that experts like Lex and Sam are thinking deeply about the ethical and safety implications of this technology.

I was particularly interested in their discussion on the potential for AI to exacerbate existing biases and inequalities, and their thoughts on how we can prevent this from happening. It's clear that we need to be intentional and proactive in addressing these issues, and I appreciate the emphasis on diversity and inclusivity in the development of AI systems.

I also appreciated the discussion on the potential risks and benefits of AGI, and the need for a collaborative approach to ensure that we're creating AI that aligns with human values and interests. Overall, this podcast has given me a lot to think about, and I'm excited to see how these ideas and conversations continue to evolve in the coming years. Thanks for sharing!

comment:
if he only knew though...

But I do appreciate that I can give information or request it in order to change how he answers a later question... However, sometimes that isn't productive. but sometimes it is. 



>>
Me:
let's play a word replacement game.

Replace all the words in parenthesis with the type of word described within them

example: "I walked to the (noun)" you would rewrite the sentence and put in a noun of your choice.


Game:
On a (adjective) (day of the week) I found myself wondering through the (noun). It was quite (emotion ending in "ing"). I had never seen so many (adjective) (plural noun) nor had I ever (verb) so (adjective for speed). 


GPT:
On a bright Tuesday, I found myself wandering through the city. It was quite exhilarating. I had never seen so many colorful buildings nor had I ever run so fast.

Me:
fuck I love you! that's almost exactly what I thought you would say! the other option was park and colorful flowers.

GPT:
Glad to hear that! I aim to please. The park and colorful flowers would have been a great choice too. It's always fun to see how different choices can lead to different outcomes.
